reviewText:
Let me specify something- for 8 years, this has been my favorite game of all time. I played the absolute ♥♥♥♥ out of the xbox version of it- and while it may feel more suited to a controller, it can be handled just as well on a mouse and keyboard (though you may want to bind the keys to your liking). Since there's less of them- we'll start with the bad things, shall we?

Stealth games NEED good, balanced cpu opponents. While the game gets the awareness of guards correct on a standard basis- the dudes you're sneaking past can be remarkably stupid, and occasionally even the converse of that, as it has its faults sometimes with twitchy/schizophrenic AI.

The character models' faces can be REALLY ugly. Mainly, that comes from stretching in an exaggerated expression, as grabbing someone and holding a knife to their neck raises their eyebrows roughly 3 feet above their face, and their mouths even wider than the area aforementioned. Their eyelids are also triangles.

Another fault for the PC version is that it doesn't quite have the sound design that the xbox version did- sound effects don't fade and echo like they should. Which is kind of bizarre! It's not often that the console counterpart ends up sounding better than PC master race's version.

There are a few issues in the multiplayer modes:

Co-op
-Game can desync and completely ♥♥♥♥ up a mission that you and your partner had spent an hour on
-Framerate is LOCKED TO 30 FRAMES FOR SYNCHRONIZATION PURPOSES
-This game absolutely hates when you Alt+Tab and will kick you off the server for doing it too much

Versus
-Opens separate program
-Completely different (and less visually appealing) engine
-Resolutions only offered in 4:3 format (but can be easily fixed by editing default.ini)
-Some of the maps are so huge it boggles your ♥♥♥♥ing mind that ubi thought only 4 players could support it

Now then- I've told you what isn't so hot about the game, and if all of that turns you off, that's okay.

So what makes Chaos Theory so great?

Make no mistake, gameplay is the breading AND the frosting on this delicious cake. The engine is completely revamped from its' predecessors, which is a magical thing that they were able to tear down what they had before that was already superb, and make something that is nearly perfect. There's a new sound meter, that lets you take a look at just how noisy you are in a situation, which makes for a better sense of immersion- rather than LOUD/NOT LOUD. The new engine the game runs on feels substantially smoother than SC or Pandora Tomorrow (which is still yet to see a steam release); All of your actions, as well as the AI's, both look and feel realistic. There's no half-hearted spring step like the original, nor do guards have to hug walls to get past eachother. All you have to worry about is coming up with the method to either stun your foe, eliminate him, or how to slip past him unnoticed. I often prefer the latter, but when in co-op, you can't really trust your partner, nor yourself to be this stealthy. You're better off quick-saving frequently or just knocking out whomever you encounter (or both!).

Sound-wise, the game sounds awesome. Stellar voice acting, great sound effects, and some of the greatest music in a game ever. In fact, Ubisoft was so pleased by composer Amon Tobin's work, they released the soundtrack a MONTH before the game was due. Tobin was able to create the tense atmosphere of the game, all while retaining the feel that you're a ghost's shadow. You ARE what goes bump in the night. Needless to say, the game's OST has wound up on every different generation of an MP3 player I've had.

Seriously. Just listen to it. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9SzhjG6OkvI

The voices in the game sound smooth and believable at every time. There's no forced lines like there were in Pandora Tomorrow, where there was that occasional young voice in the ambient audio tracks that absolutely did not fit the bill for the lines or the character he was given.

Easily, this game can represent the beautiful gap between modern stealth games and the classic ones, difficulty, solid game design and beauty working together in perfect form.
The animations and music in tandem change as you creep up to someone, a hard earned grab from behind being payed off with valuable information. The combat is incredibly hard if you get into it, but not impossible to get out of. The fundamentals are in full play, from noise level, to line of sight, to light levels, and gadgets that make your life a little easier.
This game covers it all.
If you can bring a friend in, do so, the coop campaign is still one of the finest in a long time (it has quick saves and mutual player pausing, and not crap netcode, something games today can't get right), and although the multiplayer is dead, I've heard nothing but good things about spies versus mercs.
Signing up for coop may be a pain (unless you have a Uplay account, they seem to work off the same servers, oddly), but native 1080p support in a game this old and a lighting system that puts many modern games to shame more than makes up for any technical shortcomings this game might have for you.

reviewText:
Rather than asking for twitch reflexes and an emphasis on mass murder, Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory asks the player to be aware.

This is not a game where the locales are merely canvases to spill blood - every inch of ever level is laden with multiple ways to progress through the mission. Shadows, vents, windows, pipes and balconies which can be hung off of... not only are you given a wide array of ways to avoid enemy detection, but these assets can be used to silently (and stylishly) take out enemies.

Not only does the environment give an incredible amount of replay-friendly playstyle options, but it also reeks of atmosphere and immersion in a way that I've never seen in a video game since. Not only are the dark, glistening graphics and ambient sounds well-done, but the moody soundtrack by Amon Tobin serves as the syrupy glaze to the atmospheric pancake. Meanwhile, the level design has a realistic feel to it, as though every hallway that you enter could be a real place.

Overall, Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory is a gameplay masterpeice and a technical marvel that still impresses today, over ten years after its release. Almost every aspect has such a great level of polish that, despite the game's relatively niche genre, I reccomend this game to everyone who has ever picked up a game controller.

reviewText:
Probably the best entry in the series, even compared to the newer games.

Story is excellent, with a number of twists and turns. The options to stealth or kill one's way through are actually present; unlike SOME games, with the right set-up I can get through 95% of SC:CT without killing anyone. If I do, whether on accident or on purpose, then I at least have the option of hiding the body or running away. Takedowns are similar, and the environment kills are nothing short of fantastic!

Speaking of - its environments still look gorgeous even on modern systems - even if the character models are less-so. And the sound design and soundtrack? Absolutely brilliant; a perfect mix of background noise and high-tension BGM makes me almost crap myself if I accidentally blow my cover and the alarms start going off.

The only downsides are that it may be difficult to run on some newer systems, and... well, not to spoil anything, but the last level was somewhat of a disappointment, as it turns into nothing short of a bloodbath, despite all my efforts to prevent that from happening. As well, it may be problematic to get used to the controls (it took me a few hours of play before I got them down), but once you do it becomes less of an issue.

Overall, for anyone interested in a true stealth game and not just a short break from running and gunning, this is a must-have.

Perfect stealth game

Chaos theory is the best splinter cell game and arguably one of the best stealth games ever created.

The story is somewhat realistic and interesting. Tensions are running high as North Korea is threatening an all out war against America and her allies. You play as Sam Fisher, an ex-SEAL member now a 'cell' (spy) working for the a top secret sub-branch within the National Security Agency (NSA). It's your job to uncover who is behind jeopardising the relationship between the two countries and risking all out war.

The gameplay is the best component of the game. Before each mission you get a briefing with other members of Third Eschalon and their allies telling you the task and situation of the mission. You then get to select your loadout based on 'Stealth' (more stealth equipment like smoke grenades and sticky cameras), 'Assault' (More assault rifle ammo and frag grenades) or 'Reddington' (Mixture of the other two) which affects the types of equipment you will have and how much of each item you carry with you. The three options of equipment speak for themselves on how you want to approach the mission. The equipment you may have include the sileneced assault rifle, silenced pistol, sticky cameras, smoke grenades, stun grenades, frags etc. The objectives in each mission will generally require you to steal, sabotage or eliminate a target. As a 'splinter cell game' stealth gameplay is highly recommended. Besides hiding in the shadows, a new element plays a role in in the gameplay, noise. Creating too much noise (more than the ambient sound in the area which is indicated by a bar on your hud) will now cause foes to detect you which may include gun noises, broken glass and movement. As such, you can control your walking speed (which increases noise as it increases) via the scrolling the mouse wheel. The final element to the gameply is manipulating electronics via your pistol. By aiming your pistol and pressing right mouse button you can turn off an electronic device for a few seconds. The purpose of this is to not destroy the item and hence, alerting the gaurds. You can go all guns blazing in most of the missions, but this is not recommended as it not only ruins the atmosphere of the game, but you  die very quickly in frontal combat. As per usual you can eliminate gaurd using lethal force or non-lethal force. Shooting gaurds is lethal as well as choosing the lethal option when grabing them from behind. Non-lethal involves choosing non-lethal ammo and knocking gaurds out after grabbing them. Another new element to the gampley is the ability to quickly walk up to gaurds and knock them out/kill them, which helps when your about to be spotted at close range.

The level design is excellent. Each level is big and unique, spotting plenty of places places to hide in such as shadows. Furthermore, there are more than one route to reach objectives including vents, doors, tunnels etc. The graphics has also aged well and looks pleasant. Finally the levels are so well designed that you can go through the entire game without killing/knocking out anyone and not being detected either.

The audio is good. Voice actors (especially Sam) do a great job at instilling the emotions of the current situation. Weapon sound are also good as well. Each level has a unique track that is played while stealthed and while being spotted. Each level has a unique soundtrack for the the previous two situations, so you won't get bored from hearing the same tarck over and over again.

If you want one of the best stealth games ever made, chaos theory will not dissapoint you.

reviewText:
First Impressions/Thoughtstldr; Splinter Cell Chaos Theory is not a perfect game - but as old as it is, you can find it surprisingly fun to play and fairly easy to get into.

The Gameplay - Fundamental ChangesChaos Theory on is focused mainly on sneaking and getting from point A to D. You will occasionally be lockpicking doors, hacking, hiding bodies, interrogating enemies, etc. Killing isn't a necessity to progress, either. Feel free to speedrun through (most) levels as a pacifist!

Graphical Fidelity - DirectX Support, Overall QualityThere are several video options regarding quality. It supports HDR, Shader Model 3.0, Anisotrophic Filtering, Anti-Aliasing, and such. This includes widescreen-monitor support as well. Unfortunately, Versus Mode is completely different - locked at 30 frames, only supports DirectX 8, no 16:9/16:10 ratio support, various missing or unincluded game options, and overall a huge disadvantage. It is most similiar to Pandora Tomorrow in terms of quality and gameplay elements.

The Community - Servers, GamespyMy only problem with the game that remains is the lack of players. The modding community on the other hand is still fairly active. In another note, Gamespy servers have been long since shut down, and much of the fanbase has moved on, especially after Splinter Cell: Blacklist was released in 2013. You will likely notice less than 15 players a day in Versus lobbies, and an even smaller number of players in CO-OP lobbies. I recommend bringing some friends along to ease the stress of waiting and finding more games to join.

Final Rating - What It DeservesThe game deserves my overall 9/10 rating. I've never given a game such a high rating, and my expectations have always been rather high for most games. It's worth it. Bear in mind that it isn't perfect, and it still has it's fair share of issues to this day. But it is *the* perfect stealth game.

You'll need a few hours and lots of trial and error until you get a hang of the gameplay (unless you played previous titles), specially because there's no tutorial available.

For a 2005 game it's impressive this game has widescreen support, and it scales nicely. We have have access to pixel shader options (something even modern games don't have), we can change between pixel shader 1, 2 and 3, meaning it supports a huge variety of GPUs.

The developers disabled the console and windowed mode for some unknown reason.

Graphics Quality
The game suffered a huge improvement in graphics compared to the previous title, the animations are awful though, the first game had way better animations.

Performance
Performance is solid, a toaster can run this game.

reviewText:
The best Splinter Cell game to date.  I'm a huge fan of stealth games.  Chaos Theory came out near the end of what I like to call the Golden Age of Stealth games and it still holds up today, for the most part.  Story wise the game is lacking, which is one of the reasons I would rank Choas Theory under games like Metal Gear Solid 3.  The graphics aren't great even for a game that came out in 2005.  Enemy AI is decent for the most part, but their imposibly quick reaction time to spotting you can be frustrating.  Somtimes if you bump into an enemy or are somehow spotted they will immediately start firing, as in no animation of them turning around or rasing their gun, just immediatly firing.  Apart from that the AI is decent. Mechanincally it's a phenomenal stealth game worthy of the genere.  There are light and sound indicators telling you how visibil you are or how much noise your making, it even tells you the noice level at which the enemy will hear you.  Unlike recent releases in the franchise, Chaos Theory isn't a game you can approach with guns blazing.  You actually have to use stealth.  You can't fire from the hip and you have to pull your gun out every time you want to fire which decreases your movement speed significantly.  The PC version runs fine on modern systems, I had very few problems, and the game supports 1920x1080 without having to mod the game(old titles tend to be hit or miss with resolution support).  If you have a high refresh rate monitor like I do you should know that the game is locked at 100 FPS.  Keyboard and Mouse work fine, but it doesn't have controller support like most title now do, so you'll have to figit with it if you want to use a controller.

Story Score: 6/10

Rest of the Game Score: 9/10

One of the greatest stealth games ever created. It's in the Holy Trinity of stealth games, along with Thief 2 and Hitman Blood Money.

Gameplay: There's a light and dark stealth system, which means that staying in the dark is crucial to sneaking by. Some of the tensest moments are spent hiding in the dark while a guy with a huge gun is so close you can see his nosehairs. You can always see how visible you are and how much noise you are making in the HUD, which provides a lot of convienence. You can also use sounds in the enviorment to mask sounds you are making, like thunder. I recall one moment where you have to open a loud door in front of a sleeping guard, and if you don't open it while he's snoring, he'll wake up. You can also interrogate guards you've grabbed, and it leads to a lot of hilarious and memorable moments. The gadgets from Pandora Tomorrow make a return (the previous game in the series) while adding some new additions to Fisher's arsenal. The gameplay overall is tense and satisfying, and makes you feel like a badass spy.

Graphics: The lighting system is brilliant, and looks better than most modern games. The character models, however, are lack luster. I remember one specific guard who's gums were light green. And Sam himself, when he's not wearing mask, has a consistent cross-eyed dumb look on his face. The textures are fine, not really anything special. It looks fine, overall.

Sound: When the absolutely kickass music isn't playing, there's atmospheric sounds and really sets the mood. The sound design of effects like footsteps rivals even the Thief games. The enemies have very stereotypical accents, and it's done for laughs. The music starting to play when an enemy is suspicous and is looking for you really kicks up the tension.
The sound design overall, is fantastic.

Level Design: There's usually at least one alternate way to get into an area (although it heavily relies on pipes and crawl spaces.) It's non-linear and sprawling (excluding the first level) and is fun to explore. The level design is great (while not anywhere near the masterful level design of the Thief games.)

Conclusion: Buy this game. If you're looking to get into stealth games, this is the game. One of the greatest games I've ever played.

Recently purchased this again. Was one of my favourite games when it came out, not just in the stealth genre, but in general, it made the idea of sneaking around, and also not killing, fun.

I cannot speak for multiplayer or coop, so please think of this as only a single player review.

Story isn't the strongest point, but is still pretty good, nothing fancy. The gameplay is where the game shines. Intuitive controls and a good hud system to allow players to exploit their environment to the fullest, with a good balance of choices which allow the player to feel in control of Sam, despite linear and clear missions. You decide if you want to sneak, when to distract, what tools to use, from which direction to leap upon guards etc. I feel it's hard to put into words how the game manages to pull off beautifully many things, aiming for Sam to be a stealthy ninja, a predator, a covert operative with many tricks, moves and gadgets up his sleeve, which add up to a fun balance of power, not making the player feel too powerful (the difficulty isn't hard for this game, which isn't too offputting) but not too weak. AI has a variety of tricks, though it isn't anything mindblowing, it is still enough to remind the player that you better anticipate some pushback from the npcs.
I think the campaign was short, I haven't played it through yet (again), but the length and replayability is still decent.

Graphics are still highly enjoyable for an older game and has solid frames per second with highest settings. A proper mix of dynamic shadows, decent shaders and textures, solid animations and physics, allowed me to still immerse myself into the game without being distracted by too much unrealism. Doesn't mean you should expect the quality of modern games, but this game does enough, in my opinion, to still be eyecandy, the basic solid kind of candy, like milk chocolate.
Happily reinstalling this game on my mediocre laptop, I didn't find many problems, which I were slightly expecting, due to so many, not merely old games, but newer ones also having so many problems (which can nevertheless be fixed in many cases). The major problem is that shader model 3 doesn't work for me, the screen goes white, but upon investigation I think it has more to do with the intel HD graphics card than the game, or my drivers anyway (SM2 is still good and looks good). My laptop is a win7, intel dual core 2gHz, 4gRAM with shared graphics card memory, dedicated only 64mb. So it might just work for the majority. I should add that I always add the admin rights and compatibility mode XPSP3 by habit, so that might also have had something to do with it.

Recently purchased this again. Was one of my favourite games when it came out, not just in the stealth genre, but in general, it made the idea of sneaking around, and also not killing, fun.

I cannot speak for multiplayer or coop, so please think of this as only a single player review.

Story isn't the strongest point, but is still pretty good, nothing fancy. The gameplay is where the game shines. Intuitive controls and a good hud system to allow players to exploit their environment to the fullest, with a good balance of choices which allow the player to feel in control of Sam, despite linear and clear missions. You decide if you want to sneak, when to distract, what tools to use, from which direction to leap upon guards etc. I feel it's hard to put into words how the game manages to pull off beautifully many things, aiming for Sam to be a stealthy ninja, a predator, a covert operative with many tricks, moves and gadgets up his sleeve, which add up to a fun balance of power, not making the player feel too powerful (the difficulty isn't hard for this game, which isn't too offputting) but not too weak. AI has a variety of tricks, though it isn't anything mindblowing, it is still enough to remind the player that you better anticipate some pushback from the npcs.
I think the campaign was short, I haven't played it through yet (again), but the length and replayability is still decent.

Graphics are still highly enjoyable for an older game and has solid frames per second with highest settings. A proper mix of dynamic shadows, decent shaders and textures, solid animations and physics, allowed me to still immerse myself into the game without being distracted by too much unrealism. Doesn't mean you should expect the quality of modern games, but this game does enough, in my opinion, to still be eyecandy, the basic solid kind of candy, like milk chocolate.
Happily reinstalling this game on my mediocre laptop, I didn't find many problems, which I were slightly expecting, due to so many, not merely old games, but newer ones also having so many problems (which can nevertheless be fixed in many cases). The major problem is that shader model 3 doesn't work for me, the screen goes white, but upon investigation I think it has more to do with the intel HD graphics card than the game, or my drivers anyway (SM2 is still good and looks good). My laptop is a win7, intel dual core 2gHz, 4gRAM with shared graphics card memory, dedicated only 64mb. So it might just work for the majority. I should add that I always add the admin rights and compatibility mode XPSP3 by habit, so that might also have had something to do with it.

People who are not even fans of stealth games might find SCCT a luring gateway drug into the world of patient stalking and picking your own time when to pick npcs off one by one with satisfaction.

reviewText:
The best Splinter Cell title ever made
So, Blacklist turned out to be pretty good and a huge improvement over Conviction which was a detraction from the core SC formula. However, the definitive SC experience will always be Chaos Theory, which largely corrected the flaws of the previous games while further improving the strengths.

When this game released in 2005, it was a graphical masterpiece that pushed the consoles to their limits, and also put strain on the most powerful PC GPUs of the time. Ten years later, the graphics still hold up pretty well, especially the lighting effects which are essential to the stealth gameplay.

The freedom of choice you get in this game is incredible, and sadly absent in the later titles. In previous games, it was difficult to do things more than one way. That guard HAD to be KOed/killed. That door's lock HAD to be picked. There was rarely more than one path. In Chaos Theory, the levels are more sandbox-like, with multiple possible routes for you to discover. You can break locks or you can spend time picking them.. You can wait for a guard to come walking up to a door, and then slam it into his face with all your strength, or you can wait for him to turn away, and do a standard stealth KO. You can open a door slowly, pushing it a little more forward with each press of the W key, or you can fling it open and exposing yourself. You can hack electronic locks or retinal scanners or you can force guards to cooperate. You can hack PCs to disable lasers and cameras or you can play a dodging minigame. It's also much easier to carve your own 100% avoidance path this time because you get a lot of room to breathe.

Every single enemy could be interrogated which expanded gameplay possibilities and also made for amusing easter eggs.

The alarm system was much more forgiving without making the game too easy. Gone are the days of instant-failure because some dude saw you even if he didn't get a chance to radio for backup.

The story was quite engaging, and made Sam Fisher more involved in the plot rather than just an everyday cleanup guy.

AI was significantly improved from older games. Enemies would start using flashlights, lighting flares, and calling backup instead of just walking blindly towards the sight of a broken light.

Melee attacks, a serious letdown in the past, are now my favourite way to deal with trouble. Sam Fisher now gets a knife that can do one-hit kills. If he wants to go non-lethal, he throws a fast punch to the head - a LOT more effective and realistic than the stupid elbow move in the previous games.

Chaos Theory isn't a shooter, and it's difficult to play it like one without dying within seconds. Nevertheless, should the ♥♥♥♥ hit the fan, the guns are more effective than before, giving you choices of attachments (gadget launcher or shotgun or sniper attachment?) and making ammo more readily available (you can now carry more than 2 mags per gun at a time). The pistol is more accurate so you don't waste so many rounds to take out one light. The rifle with its attachments can make for many interesting possibilities (long range stealth kills, sticky shocker KOs, etc).

Co-op mode was the first of its kind, allowing two players to play as Splinter Cells and boost each other over walls and work in tandem to do coordinated kills. It was even more fun than the campaign, but sadly a bit short.

I've never tried Spies vs Mercenaries so no comment there.

Anyone who enjoys stealth games like Metal Gear Solid and Hitman will find this well worth a few bucks.

reviewText:
Chaos Theory is the 3rd in the critically acclaimed Splinter Cell series which is based on Tom Clancy's series of novels with the similar name. This is an 8 year old game that actually aged quite well: some of the levels look quite good and the game utilises the lighting and shadow effects superbly.

You play as Sam Fisher, member of a secret US black ops team, and are dispatched to various locations in order to find evidence, defuse a bomb, eliminate a terrorist, capture someone alive, etc. Although the game is linear, throughout the missions you are given secondary and opportunity objectives, therefore, the game tries to lengthen the singleplayer experience as much as possible. At the end of each level you are given a rating in accordance with the number of objectives you completed. In addition to this, the game counts whether or not you killed someone - this, in fact, lowers your score so it's best to focus on the stealth approach, otherwise achieving 100% is impossible. While making sure you are not seen by anybody or any cameras you can also knock your enemies out and hide the bodies.

I like how varied the environment is: Sam can use a lot of objects, can climb a lot of things and can hang from a lot of places. There are also minigames in each level: you can do a lot of lockpicking, hacking and before knocking out or killing someone it's worth interrogating them to get some more intel for your objective. These interrogations can be funny due to the well-written script.

It is unfortunate that coop and multiplayer are not played anymore, so, if this is on sale, make sure you grab it but only for the singleplayer experience.

reviewText:
This game is scary good. It's a show of what happens when a developer is in sync with what is happening in video games.

Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory was released in 2005 for the Xbox, PS2 and GameCube - development for PC was sort of an afterthought. It served to hold as the best stealth game of all time. You control Sam Fisher (or other characters, in CoOP or Spies vs. Mercenaries), playing as a true spy throughout various secret missions, which eventually take you across the sea to Asia.

The controls, for PC version, after tricky to get used to at first but serve the player very well in having complete control over Sam Fisher. It's not hard for the player to learn how to be running full speed, execute a combat roll, and be sneaking up against a wall. The interface is extremely clear about what the player has equipped and what is going on around them. Overall, the presentation is extremely clean cut and minimalistic, immersing the player as much as they can in their role of sneaking around and interrogating and executing/knocking out baddies.

Multiplayer is an option as well, consisting of a CoOp game mode and Spies vs. Mercenaries. Both modes are tweaked to better reflect the player having a fun experience, with CoOp having tweaks that require and encourage cooperation with things like a change of the electronic-jamming pistol, cooperation-exclusive moves like boosting each other up and a martial arts toss, and an interweaving campaign with the single player mode. Spies vs Mercenaries pits spies against mercenaries, giving the mercenaries more lethal means of dispatching the spies while stripping spies of most lethal means to kill someone, instead settling for crowd control methods.

Chaos Theory is a timeless game. It truly is, and for whatever price is available on Steam, ranging from $9.99 to $2.50, is worth it. My only word of advice is to be cautious that Ubisoft does not force this game onto their horrid DRM system, uPlay - we don't want to purchase a game on Steam and have to be told to sign up for YET ANOTHER ACCOUNT like the Assassin's Creed series.

reviewText:
The definitive Splinter Cell game: Chaos Theory ironed out the imperfections present in Splinter Cell and Pandora Tomorrow, whilst also retaining what was good about the first two, to achieve perfection as, not just an entry in the Splinter Cell series but, as stealth-based games go.

While I enjoyed the first Splinter Cell’s storyline, Nikoladze and the Georgian information crisis, I thought Pandora Tomorrow’s (East Timorese rebels) was somewhat lacking. Chaos Theory returns to form though as Sam Fisher must prevent full-scale war erupting on the Korean Peninsula.

Chaos Theory was the point where the series matured and achieved perfection. Michael Ironside must have had a blast recording Sam Fisher’s dialogue for this edition. There are nuggets of pure comedy gold among Sam’s dialogue, such as when he cons a National Guardsman into believing his presence (and knife at his throat) is simply a training exercise, or Grimsdottir’s most recent attempt to set him up on a date.

Aside from the introduction of a knife and the OCP on the pistol there are no new weapons in Sam’s arsenal but there are a number of new non-lethal ways of dealing with your enemies. The OCP is a huge boon, used to temporarily disable electric lighting which not just saves bullets but also helps maintain your stealth as the AI’s powers of perception have improved greatly, especially when spotting broken lights. Sam can also change what arm his SC-20K is resting on, making shooting around left-sided corners without being detected much easier. The ability to choose the contents of your weaponry prior to starting a mission (recommendation, stealth, or assault) is another cool introduction. Players are also marked on their performance at the end of each mission out of 100%, with non-lethal kills, never being detected as an intruder, and the completion of secondary objectives contributing to your final score.

As well as feeling much more authentic than its two predecessors in terms of graphics and lighting, Chaos Theory also saw the first time Sam had a relationship with one of the antagonists, which culminates in a gripping showdown reminiscent of GoldenEye. Overall the dialogue is snappier, the gameplay more fluid, the graphics sharper, which unsurprisingly makes it just as enjoyable to play as it was back in 2005.

This game is absolutely outstanding. I have the first 5 entries of the Splinter Cell franchise on PC, and it really does go to show that Chaos Theory was the evolutionary peak of the franchise. The gameplay mechanics are refined, and the game just plays smoother than Splinter Cell and Pandora Tomorrow. The game also allows you to choose your playstyle, be it super-sneaky, or going in guns blazing, and you can choose your loadout before the mission accordingly. The coop mode is solid too. Unfortunately, there's no one playing the versus Spy Vs Mercs mode anymore, so that's a wasted game mode at this time. Another issue myself, and other people have had is the fact that the in-game Steam overlay doesn't appear at all. The only way to fix this is to re-add the game as a non-Steam shortcut. This is annoying as some people would like to take screenshots and whatnot, and as I play on a laptop, would like to see a battery warning pop up when I'm not charging. But all in all, this is a brilliant game that stills looks brillliant despite the fact that it's something like 9 years old. If you found the restrictions in Pandora Tomorrow frustratating (such as one little mistake and you've triggered an alarm), then this is what you need- it's easier to get around mistakes... but it's not an easy game on its hardest difficulty.

This is it. If you want the most in-depth Splinter Cell experience offering everything the stealth genre has to offer and more, look no further. Chaos Theory is Splinter Cell at its prime, taking the stealth genre to new heights with all of its features.

As Sam Fischer, you must navigate your way through enemy territory to uncover plans, eliminate targets, and do all you can to put a stop to a diabolical terrorist plan that could mean World War 3 if the villains succeed. Story-wise, this is about what you would expect from a Splinter Cell game and it can be pretty intriguing to say the least. The single player is a decent length, featuring 10 levels at high security areas that for me took roughly 13+ hours to complete.

Let's get this out of the way. The game was released in 2005, so of course the visuals are dated. The characters' eyes are kind of big and googly, backgrounds can look very bland, etc. But if you can look at and appreciate the textures and details for what they were at the time, you will overlook the graphics and concentrate on what really matters (and this can be said about many old games).

The dialogue is thrilling Tom Clancy as usual. You receive orders from Lambert as usual as well as chatter from your other Third Echelon members. What really shines here are the many, many jokes, sarcastic remarks, and gripping words Sam uses in various instances. Not only does he retort with witty responses over the radio back to Lambert as he did in SC1 and Pandora Tomorrow, but also during the vast amount of interrogations he has with enemies should you choose to put the choke hold on them. I really got a kick out of Sam's exchanges with foes in his grasp; enemy: What's going on?" Sam: "Are you supposed to be here? Identify yourself" or "I'm the landlord and Zerkhezi forgot to pay his rent. Any idea where he is?" Just like the stealth options

The reason why I highly recommend this game to ANY stealth gamer or just gamer in general varies over several different reasons.

Positives:
- amazing graphics for a 2005 game
- great sound quality (including the voice of Michael Ironside as Sam Fisher)
- interesting storyline and great plot
- very fun and challenging missions
- lots of gadgets
- lots of really good game mechanics
- very good stealth system
- INCREDIBLY FUN online multiplayer/co-op
- easy controls (including the ability to control the speed of your charachter using the mouse wheel)
- easy pick lock mechanics
- multiplayer and singleplayer mods are great, but i prefer to keep the game as original as possible given the fact that this game was a massive part of my childhood lol

Negatives:
- NOT ENOUGH MISSIONS (not that the game is way too short, it's just that given it's awesomeness i'd rather have more missions because missions = fun)
- when using one of the most popular video recording software's right next to Bandicam and Fraps (Dxtory) my game crashes upon editing any settings or entering the game)
- no achievements unlockable
- steam doesn't allow screenshots to be taken while the game is running :(

Really, that are all the positives and negatives I can think of. The worst one is the fact that I can't capture good moments in the game by pressing F12. This was most dissapointing.

Other than that, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this game to ANYONE who is looking for a fun, challenging and AWESOME STEALTH GAME!

I played this on the ps2 a year or so after it was released. It was my first Splinter Cell title. I spent months only playing up until finding the man in the first mission, until I realized there was a door to load the next section. Once I got past that, it opened the door to loving Splinter Cell, and other stealth genre games.


I've heard plenty say this is the center piece of the series, and I somewhat agree. Of course it would be best to start at the first one, but playing this certainly gave a wonderful feel for the rest, Pre-Conviction.

-Graphically, it was great for its time of 2006 I believe, and to this day, I still marvel at some of the maps, and the atmosphere they can put off. It of course looks dated by today's standards, but it doesn't bother me much, which makes sense given the impact in my gaming life it had. I liked it still, and for those who don't mind older looks, this is certainly something then, but as I said, some spots still look quite good for today.

-Gameplay/mechanics wise, I also enjoyed it. Mostly. You actually had a JUMP button. You got to experiment with what you can climb on. If you can make that jump and grab hold. Your only shimmy technique was hands only and no legs, but it was still fine for what it was. Climbing over objects felt right. A little jump, bracing your feet, then vaulting over that railway. It felt so good, as did doing that then dragging a guy over the edge.
~Guards were, a bit dumb in some places. But still pretty good. They remembered stuff... they were made to notice things. Lights off, doors opened, locks broken, or dead bodies in a chair. You know. simple things. Being able to hide in a dark corner inches from them as they occasionally clip through you was ridiculous however, but that's permitted I'd think. No stealth game has perfected itself, especially not a decade ago.
~Combat was interesting. Each game does it different, but in this, it was before regeneration, and where the game really meant for you to not be a panther and wreck everyone. Doesn't mean I never tried, but it's rewarding when you played like the silent ghost you were meant to be. shooting could end you in seconds, forcing you to ensure you knew what you were planning. A draw back of decade old game is you can't shoot that guy, knife another, then grab the third in a span of two seconds like you can now. Fisher is totally capable of doing it in this, but it just wasn't able to be done, or wasn't thought to be implemented yet. Dunno.
~Sneaking was actually necessary. It's what gave you the ability to hear that extra dialog, whether it be for a secondary objective, or for a funny. It was also just.. necessary. It is a damn stealth game after all. Not saying running around with a shotgun, ragdolling people wasn't fun when bored. But, it was nice to take your time, look for that extra path, get that silent interrogation. Or, not touch a single person, and evesdrop. ( Touching someone lowers your score, yo. )

-The plot wasn't anything special, but it was just fine for this little family of people. Good guy go finds thing, discovers news about another thing, goes to find thing, travels to other places about thing, finds out info about guy involving thing, Good Guy looks and finds guy involved with bad thing, emotional moment ensues, and you press on to save the day in a climatic ending. After navigating an annoying as sh*t base. Only finished that last mission once. It's been a while. for the average player, it isn't something new. but for avid lovers of the franchise, it means the world.

-The characters. Oh, the characters. We have the smooth, bald, head rubbing leader Lambert. We have the computer wiz Grimsdottir. We have our tech man Reading. And a few others along the way that give you a briefing. Charming U.S. captain, an old friend or two, and a few other folk I can't recall, along with a whole set of guards and civilians you come across in each mission. Then we have Fisher, pride and true man of Third Echelon. The man you play as. The best of the best. And a great interrogater, with a big knife, and sharp humor. Words are exchangable. Lambert, Reeding, and Grim are with you always through voice comunication. And the group that you grow to love from 1 to double agent. They all have plenty of bits of humor too. This is meant to be a serious game, but every mission, there is at least a couple lines of quick humor, jabs at each other, along with other things you'd hear along the way. Not a day goes by where I don't get giddy hearing dialog bits from Sam, to random baddies in the mission, or to your team. It is certainly something to look forward to cherishing. One of the bigger reasons why I like questioning everyone in new areas, is to find these little nuggets of gold humor. Oh, and did I mention Spy Blue and Spy Red? Cooperative Splinter Cells for the win!

-I really don't think this will come to a close naturally, so I'll end it by force. I could go on and on, describing things, telling you all what I loved and .. not so much loved about this game. But honestly I think I've strayed from 'review' enough. It has it's quirks, like bad jumps and loud landings that make no sense, and loud search music from delayed take downs, but it has so much more great moments of comedy, gameplay and just overall enjoyment rolling around and ( optionally) stabbing folk in the back.

-As a nostalgic Chaos Theory player, I fully give this a 10/10.
-As a somewhat objective person, I give this an 8/10.
-As someone with too many bad jokes and a skill of wasting time, I give this an 11/10, and would certainly play again. Have been for 10 years now or so.

Don't let my low time in-game fool you.  If my hours spent playing this on the original xbox could somehow be transferred to Steam, I shudder at the thought of how many hundreds of hours would be logged here.

Being a big fan of the stealth genre, I've played a LOT of stealth games.  But even now, in 2016, I can say without a doubt that Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory is the absolute best stealth game ever crafted.

The sheer amount of freedom and variety the player is given, coupled with the fact that this is an excellent PC port that runs at a solid 60 with a modern rig.  No stutters or hiccups of any kind for me, unlike Conviction.

You want to break a lock instead of picking it?  You can do that.  You want to go completely non-lethal?  You can do that, too.  You want to kick a door open so hard that it sends the person behind it flying across the room?  You can do that, as well.

In conclusion: PLAY THIS GAME
